content:
Hi! I published the eventbrite for the second, October meeting of the RFMIG focused on the questions of specifications. I accidentally published the event with the wrong date at first, it will be on October 25th (monday), not sunday.

You can find the eventbrite here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/rfmig-specifications-tickets-179529526647

I hope to see you all there :)

Hi, I just noticed that on the website (https://rust-formal-methods.github.io/) it says the meeting is at 19:00 CET (UTC + 1), while the eventbrite page says it is at 19:00 CEST (so UTC + 2) ... given that EU summer time is still in effect that week, I assume it is 19:00 CEST?
@Xavier Denis ?
hmm yes,
i'm notoriously bad at timezones sorry about that

Xavier Denis said:

Hi! I published the eventbrite for the second, October meeting of the RFMIG focused on the questions of specifications. I accidentally published the event with the wrong date at first, it will be on October 25th (monday), not sunday.

You can find the eventbrite here: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/rfmig-specifications-tickets-179529526647

I hope to see you all there :)

I tried to register, but it said "Sales have ended online
This event is no longer available online."

How do I register?

Thanks, DSN
@Xavier Denis ?
@Daniel Schwartz-Narbonne Registration should be open again
yea I opened them up this morning
he was able to sign up
is it a zoom meeting? the event page doesn't have any location info

Mario Carneiro said:

is it a zoom meeting? the event page doesn't have any location info

yes.
ah, found it
I haven't found the zoom info though :)
ah, ok
its asking me for a TK but didnt get one by email hmm
you gotta use that second link
“Join the event” in the email → “Open in Zoom” → enter your info → …
That seems to work, thanks! :smile:
https://us02web.zoom.us/meeting/register/tZUkduuqqTIrH9JM07t9N7ERR-4k0kro3Ri5
@Xavier Denis the problem is that lack of permission
unfortunately... i forgot to record the meeting this time, I'm so sorry everyone who couldn't attend
I'll post the slides on the website though
unless @Ernest Kissiedu got a copy

@Xavier Denis @Vytautas Astrauskas [he/him] @Yusuke Abe Thanks for the interesting discussion yesterday.
Is it possible to draw some preliminary conclusions about which tool to use for which kind of program?
We can state them here, and perhaps have a small digest on the homepage at some later point.

For me, it was interesting to see that creusot/rustHorn is more concise than prusti.
One suggestion is to add a section where tool developers can add a brief description of their tools and a link for more information.
This is a good point, I’ve asked a few tool developers to write sections like this already
Would you be willing to write a bit on RMC?
